abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Power Project's outcome
            is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as modest, Bank performance
            as satisfactory, and borrower performance as satisfactory.
            The outcome of expanding and improving the reliability of
            power supply was successful, although delays were
            experienced in the commissioning of the Owen Falls Extension
            hydropower plant (OFE). However, institution-strengthening
            efforts and attempts to improve Uganda Electricity
            Board's operational and financial performance fell
            short of expectations. The lessons learned include: It is
            more efficient to initiate and implement measures to improve
            institutional and financial performance in advance of major
            new investments. Government ownership of its power sector
            reform program is a critical underpinning to ensure its
            successful and timely implementation. The inclusion of the
            Dispute Review Board (DRB) should be reviewed as it could be
            counterproductive to the dispute resolution process. The
            removal of amicable settlement with the introduction of the
            DRB could also delay the resolution of disputes because if
            DRB's recommendation were to be rejected, the next step
            would be arbitration. Procurement capacity should be built
            prior to commencement of implementation in order to avoid
            delays caused by poor procurement decisions, as was the case
            concerning the first civil works contract for OFE.
